title: Sergei Eisenstein is born.Photo of Sergei Eisensteins mother, father and grandmother
description: Sergei Eisenstein is born in Riga in Nikolai Street 6, apartment no. 7.Michaïl Ossipovič Eisenstein (father),  Julija Ivanova (mother) and Iraïda Mateevna Koneckij (grandmother), Riga 1897

title: Eisenstein is baptized.
description: Sergei Eisenstein is baptized in Riga Cathedral.

title: Has earliest childhood memories of a summer stay in the country at Riga Bay.
description: Sergei Eisenstein spends the summer at the Riga Bay. He dates his earliest childhood memories back to this stay in the country. "A branch of white lilac, striped by a diagonally falling sunbeam, looks in through the window. Swings above me. My first conscious impression - the close-up." (Stationen. Autobiographische Aufzeichnungen. Ü.: R. Braun. Berlin/DDR 1967., p. 367) In connection with the experience of later reading Edgar Allan Poes arabesque The Sphinx (1846), he attributes his interest in foreground composition to this fragment of memory.

title: Sees an amateur theatre performance by his relatives.
description: Again Sergei Eisenstein spends the summer in a summer house at the Riga Bay. He sees an amateur performance of The Butler Did It. His relatives stage the play.

title: Witnesses the repression of demonstrators by the tsarist police during the First Russian Revolution.
description: Sergei Eisenstein witnesses the repression of demonstrators by the tsarist police during the First Russian Revolution.

title: Travels to Paris with his parents.
description: Sergei Eisenstein travels to Paris with his parents. They stay at the Hotel Du Helder in Rue du Helder. He has his first cinema going experience. He visits Napoleons tomb, Notre Dame, the Botanical Garden and the waxworks cabinet in the Musée Grevin. Scenes from the waxwork inspire him while working on the Sergei Tretjakov play Can You Hear Me, Moscow? and his own film October.

title: Sergei Eisensteins parents separate.
description: Sergei Eisensteins mother Julija Ivanova separates from her husband and moves to St. Petersburg to Tavričeskaja street 9. Sergei Eisenstein stays with his father in Riga.

title: Sergei Eisenstein learns English and French
description: Sergei Eisenstein is learning English and French; since he lives in Riga, he already speaks better German than Russian.

title: Discovers caricatures of André Gill and Honoré Daumier
description: In his fathers library Sergei Eisenstein finds a book entitled Das Jahr 1871 und die Pariser Kommune;, in which he discovers caricatures of André Gill and Honoré Daumier, which fascinate him so much that he persuades the housekeeper to buy a Daumier monograph. In a later study of the sensation of a movement sequence, he draws conclusions from Daumiers caricatures about the construction of an artificially generated movement.

title: Begins to draw.
description: Inspired by an employee of his father, engineer Afrossimov, Sergei Eisenstein begins to draw "very much and very badly". With time, his interest concentrates on pure line drawing.

title: First visit to a circus performance in St. Petersburg.
description: Sergei Eisenstein for the first time visits a circus performance in St. Petersburg. He soon becomes a passionate follower of the circus. The principle of a program based on numbers determines the structure of his early theatrical productions, which break down each fragment of a play into artistic attractions and work with the eccentric elements of the circus and the Music Hall (clowns, tightrope walkers, acrobats). The structure of a circus performance is at the same time the starting point for the development of the idea of Montage.

title: Intense interest for the French Revolution.
description: Inspired by the reading of French revolutionary novels, Sergei Eisenstein asks for Histoire de la Revolution française by François Auguste Mignet for Christmas.

title: Watches his first color film.
description: Sergei Eisenstein watches the first "films in natural colors […]."

title: Watching a cruel film scene becomes a traumatic experience.
description: The cruelty of a film scene in which a blacksmith burns a convicts mark on the shoulder of a sergeant in revenge, together with the reading of the novels The Torture Garden (1899) by Octave Mirabeau and Venus in Furs (1870) by Leopold von Sacher-Masoch are a traumatic experience for Sergei Eisenstein, "until the ocean of cruelties that my own films are filled with [...] flooded these early impressions of the disastrous film and the two books that undoubtedly influenced this ocean".

title: Parents get divorce.

title: Processes politics and his school life in drawings.
description: Sergei Eisenstein draws a lot. Over the years he begins to occupy himself with a series of satirical drawings in his sketch books - In the World of Animals - in which daily political events, personalities of Riga society and school events are processed.

title: Spends the summer with his mother in Staraja Russa.
description: Sergei Eisenstein spends the summer with his mother in Staraja Russa. There he experiences a procession that later inspires him to the church procession in the film The General Line. During the stay he meets Anna Grigorjevna Dostoevskaja, the widow and executor of Fëdor Dostoevskijs estate.

title: The family is evacuated from Riga due to the war. Sergei Eisenstein travels to Petrograd to enter the Institute of Civil Engineering.
description: Families of officials are evacuated from Riga in anticipation of German troops advancing on Lithuania and Kurland since April 1915. Sergei Eisenstein travels with his father to Petrograd for the entry exam to the Institute of Civil Engineering. During the trip he rebels against his authoritarian father for the first time.

title: Starts living in Petrograd.
description: From his entrance exam to the Institute of Civil Engineering on Sergei Eisenstein lives with his mother until 1918.

title: Begins his studies at the Institute of Civil Engineering.
description: Sergei Eisenstein starts his studies at the Institute of Civil Engineering in Petrograd. He is intensively engaged in analytic geometry.

title: Occupation with the art of Italian Renaissance.
description: Sergei Eisenstein occupies himself with the art of Italian Renaissance. The theatrical means of the mask in the Commedia dellArte is decisive for the development of the Character Typage in Sergei Eisensteins films.

title: Visits the Vaudeville theaters in Petrograd.
description: Sergei Eisenstein visits the Vaudeville Theatres in Petrograd and meets the theater director Nikolaj Evreïnov.

title: Becomes a city militiaman.

title: Takes the exam in Higher Mathematics.
description: Sergei Eisenstein takes the exam in Higher Mathematics.

title: Visits the repertoire productions of Meyerhold.
description: Sergei Eisenstein visits the repertoire productions of Vsevolod Meyerhold at the Aleksandrinskij Theatre: Molière, Don Juan (on the program since November 9, 1910) and Calderón de la Barca, The Constant Prince (on the program since April 23, 1914). The traditional costume, mask and decoration designs from the year 1917 that are preserved in the Sergei Eisenstein Archive may, among other things, be directly related to these theatrical experiences.

title: Outbreak of the February Revolution in Petrograd.
description: Outbreak of the February Revolution in Petrograd: Troops defect to the insurgents; a provisional executive committee of the Council of Workers and Soldiers Deputies is formed. Sergei Eisenstein observes the actions, but never participates actively.

title: Seeing the Meyerhold production of Masquerade has lasting impact on Sergei Eisenstein.
description: Sergei Eisenstein sees the new Meyerhold production Masquerade (1835/36) by Mikhail J. Lermontov at the Aleksandrinskij Theatre. He is very impressed and later describes it as the final blow to dedicate his life to art.

title: First caricatures get published in newspapers.
description: Sergei Eisenstein starts professionally drawing caricatures, which are initially rejected by the magazine Satirikon. The editor of the Petrograd Gazette accepts a drawing showing "the police, restoring order" for publication; Sergei Eisenstein receives a fee of 10 rubles. Other caricatures appear with the signature "Sir Gay" (= Sergei).

title: Begins studying at the School of Warrant Officers of the Corps of Engineers
description: Sergei Eisensteins application for admission to the School of Warrant Officers of the Corps of Engineers in Petrograd is accepted. He takes his first courses at the school not after July.

title: Is caught up in Bolshevik demonstrations at Nevskij Prospect.
description: Sergei Eisenstein is caught up in Bolshevik demonstrations at Nevskij Prospect, which are dispersed by military intervention. Ten years later, after personal memories and historical film and photo documents, he shoots the film October there.

title: Is sent to the front with the School of Warrant Officers of the Corps of Engineers.
description: Sergei Eisenstein is sent to the front. The School of Warrant Officers of the Corps of Engineers is used for defense "in the forecourt of Petrograd in front of the "anrückenden Haufen Kornilovs und der wilden Division«.

title: First thoughts on the principle of counterpoint.
description: In autumn while practicing building pontoon bridges, Sergei Eisenstein has his first insights concerning the principle of counterpoint "as a strictly limited combination of countless independent individual actions".

title: Reads Albrecht Dürers Diary of his journey to the Netherlands.

The author has not been identified. In 1919 or 1920 Sergei Eisenstein works on drafts for the opera Dubrovskij from Eduard Napravnik after a story by Aleksandr Puškin, on A Play about George the Brave by Vasilij Rozanov and the drama The King’s Barber by Anatolij V. description: Sergei Eisenstein begins with the montage of 49,000 meters of recorded material for October and works on the montage principle of intellectual film: two sequence parts (pictograms) that exist independently of each other in their meanings are assigned to each other contrapuntally; from the dynamic collision of the pictograms, a "decision about what is being portrayed (read: the conclusion from what is portrayed)", an intellectual concept, emerges in the viewer. A film structured in a complex way according to this principle can finally give rise to a whole system of concepts through the contrapuntal use of emotional, documentary, graphic, color, in short artistic means of influence. In October Sergei Eisenstein tries to realize this principle in two sequences (Kerenskijs staircase ascent and Gods sequence).On the door of the montage room hangs the note: "Here we are working on October. Think about it before you enter."

His expressiveness and the accuracy of his thinking, but also the illuminating insight he attributed to certain words, gave his ideas a clear, understandable form. There could be no doubt that he would make his mark on the world as a rich man in the spirit of Karl Marx: As a man for whom his own fulfilment had become an inner necessity, a need [...] He was particularly curious and interested in questions of Futurism, Constructivism and Surrealism. Jacques Feyders Visages denfants was shown at a party given for me, and I was surprised how cleverly Sergei Eisenstein analysed the merits and demerits of the film, even though few French films came to Moscow at the time - a state of affairs, incidentally, that Russian filmmakers could not complain about enough."

description: Sergei Eisenstein meets with the main representatives of the Novyi LEF in the house of Sergei Tretjakov. Even before the premiere of October, Eisenstein is heavily attacked by this group, as he does not present the October events as a documentary sequence of factographic material, but as an artistic game. Sergei Eisenstein has nothing in common with the dogmatic demand of the Novyi LEF for documentary, unposed reproduction of real material, the schematic separation of feature and documentary film. A little later he explains with a clear allusion to Novyi Lef: "The theoretical novelty - the documentary film - replaced the subject with the fact. Illusion against material. The replacement of aesthetic fetishisation was followed by a fetishism of material. But fetishism of the material is not yet materialism. It remains above all fetishism [...] The newly turned page must now be approached with the radically opposite motto: Scepticism of the material." With this, the separation from the LEF group is completed.

title: Sergei Eisenstein begins with the montage of The General Line, developing and using the principle of Overtone Montage.
description: Sergei Eisenstein begins with the montage of The General Line. At the same time, still under the impression of the Kabuki Theater, he works on the theoretical questions of Overtone Montage. He develops its principle under the impression of the monistic ensemble of Kabuki, in which every element (sound – movement – space – voice) is treated in a way that is identical in meaning: Various stimulus sources are combined in one picture; their composition lines are then not, as is usually the case, subordinated to a dominant in the course of the sequence, but are developed simultaneously in polyphonic montage. Just as in music there are so-called overtones and undertones in addition to the dominant keynote, so does "this optical play with the film material being recorded together with all its secondary tones [...] result in a visual overtone complex when in perfect harmony with the music". According to the principle of transitionl-fee playing, the abrupt change of emotional expression in the Kabuki, Eisenstein edits for example the separator sequence: "By separating polar stages of facial expression [...] sharper precision is achieved in the <playing of doubt> around the separator. Does the milk condense or not? Fraud? Money? Here the psychological process of playing the motives - of faith and doubt - broken down into the two borders - of the joyful (certainty) and the dark (disappointment)."

In addition, Eisenstein follows the principle of typage and the representation by laymen as much as possible. From Leydas production diary it becomes clear with what care Sergei Eisenstein works on the selection of the actors.

But is this that generalization, that generalization that Marxist realism teaches us? No. That is why in my work the general absorbs the individual. Instead of generalizing about the concrete, the individual, the generalization evaporates into something abstractly detached [...] I have created a film that is not the flesh and blood of our socialist reality, but rather the result of a combination of associations and a theoretical idea of this reality."

title: Sergei Eisenstein makes the final decision to direct Aleksandr Nevskij.
description: Sergei Eisenstein notes the final decision to stage Aleksandr Nevskij. He initially concentrated again on the study of historical materials. In doing so, he is confronted with the fundamental problem of historical film: to present the ideas, behavior and customs of a long past epoch in such a way that they arouse the interest of the viewer without distorting historic events. Studying old chronicles, he observes that the spirit of the events of the 13th century speaks of the same feeling that moved the people of his time and in this connection he discovers an almost literal correspondence between a newspaper report on the destruction of Guernica and a historical account of the destruction of Pskov. Another problem, the depiction of 13th-century man, is solved when visiting a church in Pereslavl-Zalesskij. From a commemorative plaque Sergei Eisenstein deduces that the church was built in a few months. For him this changes at a stroke the relationship with the stone columns, arches and ceilings: they now suddenly spoke to him as living witnesses of human labour. From them shone the image of creative work as an element of life. In this way Eisenstein also solves the most important task of freeing Aleksandr Nevskijs "holiness" from its religious glory and reducing it to its core. He defines the attribute "the saint" as "the highest form of esteem". Thus the historical consideration of our current theme has also made the hero appear as the man he was: as the only victor Nevskij possessed by the great idea of power and independence of the homeland.

When recording music, Prokofev experimented with new recording methods that exploited the shortcomings of technology to produce dramatic effects. Sergei Eisenstein and Prokofev discuss the character of the music of the episode of the Battle of the Ice Lake, to which Sergei Eisenstein wanted Prokofevs music before the recordings began. Eisenstein presented Prokofev with the cadres he had drawn for the film, including Aleksandr Nevskij on the Crows Rock, the Russian warriors, the overall plan of their arrangement, the plan of the wedge-shaped arrangement of the infantry and the Crusaders, etc. At the same time, he told how he thought of The Battle of Ice Lake in the montage.

title: Shooting for the Battle of the Ice.
description: Shooting for the Battle of the Ice on a field covered with chalk, sawdust and naphthalene near the Mosfilm studios. "We did not try to make the audience believe that thedetails of the Russian winter were real. Rather, we limited ourselves to the reproduction of the sound and color proportions of winter: white background under a dark cloudy sky. But we did more than that: we never lost sight of the character of the film, we did not play the winter, but the battle. Winter only appeared as far as it seemed real. The secret of our success lies in this description, in this reduction of the winter elements to the most essential. Part of the effect of this sequence is attributed to Eduard Tissés camera work: "The devil may know with what sophisticated technical tricks, but always clearly perceptible, Tissé sometimes achieves an almost astonishingly real color illusion."

title: Sergei Eisenstein works on the editing of the Aleksandr Nevskij.
description: Sergei Eisenstein works on the editing of the Aleksandr Nevskij. For the first time Sergei Eisenstein deals extensively with the montage of optical and acoustic pictograms in practice. He develops a principle which he later calls vertical montage, a further development of the polyphonic structure according to which the supplication procession was mounted in The General Line. In the montage, he attempts to bring the horizontal lines of the optical and acoustic drawing section, which in their individual parts interact vertically and determine each other in their expressive quality, to a qualitatively new, organic unity. He defines it using the example of the Battleship Potemkin: "A single, uniform law permeates not only the general whole and each of its individual parts, but also each area that has to participate in the creation of the whole.

title: World premiere of Aleksandr Nevskij at the House of Film.
description: World premiere of Aleksandr Nevskij at the House of Film. In the introductory speech Sergei Eisenstein thanks Joseph Stalin for his support in the production of the film. With this film, Sergei Eisenstein  restores his long-doubted reputation as a responsible Soviet film artist. Because of the patriotic theme and Sergei Eisenstein s largely renunciation of cinematographic experiments, Aleksandr Nevskij is very popular with the Russian film public. Eisensteins directorial achievement was not as undisputed as one might conclude from the subsequent official honors. Aleksandr Dovženko formulated his criticism at the conference convened in February 1940 on questions of historical and historical-revolutionary film. According to Dovženko Eisenstein had fallen into the captivity of painting. In the Federal Republic of Germany Aleksandr Nevskij remained almost unknown. The first review appears in 1952 and, apart from complete ignorance of artistic intentions, is nothing more than a vile defamation in the terminology of the Cold War. It was not until 1966, after Ivan the Terrible II had already started, that a distributor succeeded in getting the film through the censorship without any cuts. This first complete screening after 28 years was registered only reluctantly by the critics; among the few existing reviews, most of which offer only summaries or absurd interpretations, only one of them reveals an examination of Eisensteins film theoretical concept. After Aleksandr Nevskij had once passed through the cinemachains, he disappeared again in the archives and can be seen today only in seminar screenings.
